venture: Karachi Hyperlocal Real-Time Grocery Availability App

kpis.name: Budget Holder Validation
kpis.description: Percentage of interviewees who are budget holders or can access budget holders for purchasing decisions
key_evidence: Interview #1: Direct holder - 'Rs. 2,500-3,000/week on groceries, I decide what to buy'
Interview #6: Direct holder - 'I manage household budget, would pay Rs. 200/delivery for reliability'
Interview #10: Direct holder - 'Dual income, we decide together, Rs. 4,500/week'
Interview #5: Needs consideration - 'We'd discuss any new service, but price-sensitive'
Interview #8: Needs consideration - 'Extended family budget, price-conscious, would need to justify'

kpis.name: Price Acceptance Rate
kpis.description: Percentage of interviewees who find proposed pricing acceptable
key_evidence: Interview #6: 'I would pay Rs. 200 per delivery if I knew for certain the items would arrive within an hour'
Interview #1: 'Currently pays Rs. 500/week delivery = Rs. 125/delivery average, would pay similar'
Interview #10: 'Uses Careem Rs. 1,200/week = Rs. 300/trip average — Rs. 100-150 cheaper'
Interview #3: 'Willing to pay Rs. 50-100 delivery premium for convenience'
Interview #5: Price-sensitive - 'No current delivery spend, depends on pricing'

kpis.name: Current Spend Evidence
kpis.description: Percentage of interviewees with documented current spend on problem/solution
key_evidence: Interview #1: Rs. 14,500/month (groceries + delivery)
Interview #6: Rs. 27,200/month (highest delivery spend, Rs. 800/week)
Interview #9: Rs. 40,000/month (business owner, wholesale)
Interview #10: Rs. 23,800/month (uses Careem Rs. 1,200/week for grocery runs)
Interview #12: Rs. 7,200/month (lowest spend, underserved area)

kpis.name: Purchase Intent Score
kpis.description: Average purchase intent rating on 1-10 scale
key_evidence: Interview #6 (10/10): 'Would definitely buy — I would pay Rs. 200 per delivery if certain items arrive within an hour'
Interview #10 (10/10): 'Would definitely buy — We both WFH but still can't get groceries easily'
Interview #2 (10/10): 'Would definitely buy — During rain season, I can't get vegetables delivered for days'
Interview #1 (8/10): 'Would likely buy — Daraz is slow, if real inventory and 30-45 min, I'd switch immediately'
Interview #3 (8/10): 'Would likely buy — Krave Mart showed item in stock then cancelled, live inventory prevents that'

pricing_recommendations.positioning: Price competitively with market (Rs. 49-199 range), win on reliability and transparency, not price wars

decision_framework.rationale: All 4 WTP KPIs passed with strong margins. Budget authority confirmed (75%), price acceptance validated (75%), current spend documented (100%), purchase intent high (8.0/10).

risks.mitigation: Win on reliability + transparency, not price wars; offer free delivery >Rs. 1,500
Target with free delivery threshold, promotional pricing, bulk order incentives
Leverage high switching willingness (75%), referral programs, early adopter network

next_actions: Finalize pricing tiers (Standard Rs. 50-100, Premium Rs. 150-200, Free >Rs. 1,500)
Recruit 5-10 design partners from high-intent interviewees for beta
Validate unit economics model (delivery cost vs. fee revenue)
Launch beta in DHA/Clifton/Gulshan with tiered pricing
